message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the rash on the arms without involvement of perioral skin suggest erythema infectiosum (also known as fifth disease). Rubella will cause a rash starting on the face and spreading to the trunk and extremities, while exanthem subitum (also known as roseola infantum) will cause a rash after resolution of high fever. Scarlet fever presents with a sandpaper-like rash and involves the perioral skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given information and the photograph suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Rubella would have lymphadenopathy and may involve the perioral skin, Exanthem subitum would have a high fever that suddenly disappears and Scarlet fever would have a rash with sandpaper texture and possible strawberry tongue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the appearance of the rash on the extremities suggest erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Rubella causes a rash that starts on the face and spreads downwards, exanthem subitum causes a rash that starts on the trunk and spreads upwards, and scarlet fever typically has a sandpaper-like rash and involves the perioral skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, headache, and a rash that started on the face and later involved the extremities is consistent with erythema infectiosum, or fifth disease. The rash is characteristically erythematous and maculopapular, with a “slapped-cheek” appearance on the face. Rubella and exanthem subitum are also viral infections that can cause rashes, but their presentations are different. Scarlet fever is caused by group A streptococcus and typically presents with a sandpaper-like rash and fever.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash, as well as the history of a facial rash not involving the perioral skin, is consistent with erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Rubella can cause rash on the face and chest, but it usually starts on the face and spreads downward. Exanthem subitum, also known as roseola, usually starts with a high fever and then a rash appears, but the rash is not itchy. Scarlet fever is accompanied by a high fever and a sandpaper-like rash that usually starts on the neck and chest.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. The characteristic “slapped cheek” rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the limbs is classic for this condition. Rubella would cause a generalized rash and Exanthem subitum would cause a roseola-like rash. Scarlet fever would have a sandpaper-like rash.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given symptoms suggest erythema infectiosum (also known as Fifth disease) which typically presents with a "slapped cheek" facial rash followed by a lacy, pruritic rash on the trunk and extremities. Rubella presents with a similar rash but also involves the face beyond the cheek area. Exanthem subitum (also known as Roseola) presents with a high fever followed by a maculopapular rash. Scarlet fever presents with an erythematous rash that typically involves the face, trunk, and extremities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rash description and timing of symptoms suggest erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Rubella rash usually starts on the face and spreads down the body, exanthem subitum rash usually appears after a fever has disappeared, and scarlet fever rash typically involves the perioral skin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash and the history of a preceding fever and rhinorrhea indicate erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. Rubella would have a rash behind the ears and on the face, while exanthem subitum would have a fever followed by a rash on the trunk. Scarlet fever would have a sandpaper-like rash with a strawberry tongue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms that the patient has, including low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, headache, and a rash on the trunk and extremities, suggest erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease. The rash typically starts on the cheeks and spreads to the trunk and limbs. The presented photograph also matches the description of the rash in erythema infectiosum. Rubella typically presents with a rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities. Exanthem subitum (also known as roseola) presents with high fever and a rash that starts on the trunk and then spreads to the extremities. Scarlet fever typically presents with a sandpaper-like rash that starts on the trunk and then spreads to the extremities.
